session.description: This session aimed to share the learnings of the Open Data Incubator for Europe (ODINE) programme and the experience of the incubated companies. ODINE follows a unique approach for supporting the Open Data ecosystem. During this session, panelists showed and shared progress, success and learnings of the last 18 months of the programme. ODINE project, funded with a grant from the EU’s Horizon 2020 programme, will award a total of €5.5 million to selected business. By September 2016, ODINE had incubated 48 companies in 16 countries, creating more than 220 jobs.

conference_notes:
• Among the lessons learned, participants highlighted strong points: its agile services and processes; everything is open by default; there is an assigned ODINE advisor as first point of contact; customized advisor services by humans; and flexibility in red tape issues. Panelists detected several barriers and weaknesses: sales cycle with customers is sometimes longer due to lack of trust; peer-to-peer support is challenging given that companies operate in different sectors and markets.
  • Apart from panelists, among the attendees, there were some ODINE funded companies representing the variety of companies taking part of the programme: SIRIS Academic, consultancy company specialized on education and knowledge management;
  • Open Gazettes, an aggregator of government gazettes; Open Corporates, the world's largest open database of the corporate world; urbanData Analytics, analysis of the real estate data to take better and accurate economic decisions; Environment Systems, an innovative environmental and geographic information consultancy; OpenOil, a social business to develop open data frameworks for natural resources management; and Ask Helmut, a tool to find concerts, movies, art shows, and dance events in Germany.
  • ODINE has recently concluded the fourth incubation round (out of eight) so the programme continues and the expectations are high.
name: Learnings from Open Data Incubator for Europe (ODINE)
